title: Poll: Majority of Brits want to leave the EU — but oppose a no-deal Brexit
text:
According to the polling, 54 percent of the British public support the U.K. abiding by the referendum result and leaving the EU | Peter Summers/Getty Images Poll: Majority of Brits want to leave the EU — but oppose a no-deal Brexit Most British people favour abiding by the 2016 Brexit referendum result and leaving the EU.

More than 50 percent of British people are in favor of honoring the result of the 2016 referendum and leaving the EU, irrespective of whether they voted Leave or Remain, according to a new survey.

The survey — carried out for Channel 5 and ITN, which described it as the "biggest" poll on Brexit since the referendum — also shows that a majority of respondents think a no-deal Brexit would be bad for the country.

The data comes as Brexit talks enter a crucial phase ahead of this week's European Council summit.

According to the polling, 54 percent of the British public support the U.K. abiding by the referendum result and leaving the EU, with 32 percent against leaving and 14 percent who didn't know.

Asked if they support Boris Johnson’s pledge that the U.K. should leave on October 31, with or without a deal, 43 percent said they did support it, 44 percent oppose that stance and 13 percent didn't know.

There are also splits in public opinion across the country, with London, Scotland and Northern Ireland being the most strongly opposed to leaving the EU, most strongly in favour of a second referendum and also those who most strongly believe a no-deal Brexit is bad. POLITICO's own poll of polls shows that in a hypothetical second referendum, 50 percent would vote Remain and 44 percent Leave, with the rest undecided.

On the role of the queen, half of respondents said she should not intervene to remove Johnson if he has no deal in place by October 19 and fails to ask for an extension, with 35 percent saying the monarch should intervene and 14 percent unsure. Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay on Wednesday said that Johnson will comply with the Benn Act, which forces him to request an extension to Brexit negotiations if no deal is reached by October 19.

The survey was carried out between October 2 and 14, and involved 26,000 British adults.
description: Most British people favour abiding by the 2016 Brexit referendum result and leaving the EU.
